metadata.principle: Inversion - Avoid stupidity rather than seeking brilliance

failure_modes.name: Misaligned Incentive Blindness
failure_modes.description: Failing to recognize when incentives are misaligned with desired outcomes
failure_modes.mechanism: The brain rationalizes behavior that serves self-interest, making it invisible to conscious awareness
failure_modes.psychological_root: Self-serving bias combined with motivated reasoning

real_world_cases.name: Wells Fargo Fake Accounts Scandal (2016)
real_world_cases.what_happened: Employees created 3.5 million fake accounts to meet aggressive sales quotas
real_world_cases.incentive_structure: Cross-selling quotas tied to bonuses and job security
real_world_cases.failure_point: Management assumed employees would meet targets ethically
real_world_cases.outcome: $3B in fines, CEO resignation, massive reputation damage
real_world_cases.lesson: When you pay people to hit numbers, they will hit numbers - by any means

real_world_cases.name: Enron Energy Trading
real_world_cases.what_happened: Traders manipulated California energy markets causing blackouts
real_world_cases.incentive_structure: Bonuses tied to trading profits with no downside
real_world_cases.failure_point: Asymmetric risk/reward created moral hazard
real_world_cases.lesson: Unlimited upside with limited downside guarantees bad behavior

real_world_cases.name: Subprime Mortgage Crisis (2008)
real_world_cases.what_happened: Mortgage brokers sold loans to people who couldn't afford them
real_world_cases.incentive_structure: Commissions on loan volume, not loan quality
real_world_cases.failure_point: Originators had no skin in the game for loan performance
real_world_cases.lesson: Separate the risk-taker from the risk-bearer and disaster follows

critical_thresholds: Targets increased > 20% YoY without resource increase

behavioral_signals: Employees gaming metrics rather than improving outcomes
High turnover in roles with aggressive targets
Customer complaints rising while metrics look good
Middle managers hiding problems from senior leadership

safeguards.action: Align incentives with long-term outcomes
safeguards.implementation: 3-year vesting on bonuses, clawback provisions

safeguards.action: Ask: 'How could someone game this?'
safeguards.implementation: Red team every incentive structure before launch

safeguards.action: Create whistleblower protections
safeguards.implementation: Anonymous reporting, guaranteed non-retaliation

failure_modes.name: Professional Advice Corruption
failure_modes.description: Trusting advice from those who profit from your decisions
failure_modes.mechanism: Advisors unconsciously skew recommendations toward higher-commission products
failure_modes.psychological_root: Even honest people rationalize self-serving advice as 'best for client'

real_world_cases.name: Financial Advisor Churning
real_world_cases.what_happened: Advisors excessively trade client accounts to generate commissions
real_world_cases.incentive_structure: Commission per trade, not portfolio performance
real_world_cases.failure_point: Client trusted advisor's 'expertise'
real_world_cases.outcome: Billions in unnecessary fees, poor returns
real_world_cases.lesson: Ask how your advisor gets paid before taking advice

real_world_cases.name: Pharmaceutical Sales to Doctors
real_world_cases.what_happened: Drug companies paid doctors to prescribe specific medications
real_world_cases.incentive_structure: Speaking fees, consulting payments, free samples
real_world_cases.failure_point: Patients assumed doctors prescribed based on efficacy alone
real_world_cases.outcome: Opioid epidemic, overprescription of expensive drugs
real_world_cases.lesson: Even highly educated professionals are influenced by incentives

warning_signs: Recommended products have higher fees than alternatives
critical_thresholds: Advisor earns > 3x on recommended vs alternative products

behavioral_signals: Advisor dismisses lower-cost alternatives without explanation
Complex products when simple ones would suffice

safeguards.action: Use fee-only advisors with fiduciary duty
safeguards.implementation: Verify fiduciary status in writing

safeguards.action: Always ask: 'How do you get paid?'
safeguards.implementation: Require written disclosure of all compensation

failure_modes.name: Self-Deception Under Incentives
failure_modes.description: Believing your own biased reasoning when incentives are involved
failure_modes.mechanism: The unconscious mind constructs elaborate justifications for self-serving conclusions

real_world_cases.name: Theranos
real_world_cases.what_happened: Elizabeth Holmes convinced herself faulty technology worked
real_world_cases.failure_point: Incentives so large they corrupted perception of reality
real_world_cases.lesson: The bigger the prize, the stronger the self-deception

safeguards.action: Assume you are biased when you have skin in the game
safeguards.implementation: Seek disconfirming evidence from disinterested parties

failure_modes.name: Incentive Cascade Failure
failure_modes.description: Misaligned incentives at one level cascade through entire organizations
failure_modes.mechanism: Each layer optimizes for their incentives, compounding misalignment

real_world_cases.name: Boeing 737 MAX
real_world_cases.what_happened: Safety compromised to meet delivery schedules and compete with Airbus
real_world_cases.incentive_structure: Executive bonuses tied to delivery numbers and stock price
real_world_cases.failure_point: Safety engineers overruled by schedule pressure
real_world_cases.lesson: When incentives conflict with safety, safety loses without structural protection

safeguards.action: Create independent safety/quality functions with veto power
safeguards.implementation: Safety officers report to board, not CEO

failure_modes.name: Delayed Consequence Blindness
failure_modes.description: Incentives for short-term gains blind us to long-term consequences
failure_modes.mechanism: Immediate rewards activate dopamine; distant consequences don't

real_world_cases.name: Quarterly Earnings Pressure
real_world_cases.what_happened: Companies cut R&D to meet quarterly targets
real_world_cases.incentive_structure: Executive comp tied to quarterly EPS
real_world_cases.failure_point: Market rewards short-term, punishes long-term investment
real_world_cases.lesson: What gets measured gets managed - even when it shouldn't be

safeguards.action: Extend measurement periods
safeguards.implementation: 5-year rolling metrics, deferred compensation

failure_modes.name: Herd Behavior in Markets
failure_modes.description: Following the crowd into bubbles and panics
failure_modes.mechanism: Uncertainty triggers reliance on others' behavior as information

real_world_cases.name: Dot-com Bubble (1999-2000)
real_world_cases.what_happened: Investors piled into unprofitable tech stocks because everyone else was
real_world_cases.failure_point: Social proof overrode fundamental analysis
real_world_cases.lesson: When everyone agrees, everyone is probably wrong

real_world_cases.name: GameStop Short Squeeze (2021)
real_world_cases.what_happened: Retail investors bought GME because Reddit said to
real_world_cases.failure_point: Social proof from anonymous strangers
real_world_cases.outcome: Many retail investors bought at peak and lost 80%+
real_world_cases.lesson: Social proof from crowds with no skin in the game is dangerous

warning_signs: Asset price > 2 standard deviations from historical mean

safeguards.action: Invert: What would I do if no one else was doing this?
safeguards.implementation: Write investment thesis before checking what others think

failure_modes.name: Expert Social Proof Failure
failure_modes.description: Following experts who are themselves following each other
failure_modes.mechanism: Experts reference each other, creating circular validation

real_world_cases.name: Rating Agency Failures (2008)
real_world_cases.what_happened: All rating agencies gave AAA to toxic mortgage securities
real_world_cases.failure_point: Agencies copied each other's methodologies
real_world_cases.outcome: Systemic risk hidden behind false consensus
real_world_cases.lesson: Expert consensus can be expert groupthink

safeguards.action: Trace expert opinions to primary sources
safeguards.implementation: Ask: 'What is the original evidence, not the consensus?'

failure_modes.name: Manufactured Social Proof
failure_modes.description: Falling for artificially created appearance of consensus
failure_modes.mechanism: Fake reviews, bot followers, paid endorsements create false signals

real_world_cases.name: Fyre Festival
real_world_cases.what_happened: Influencer marketing created illusion of legitimate event
real_world_cases.failure_point: Attendees trusted influencer social proof
real_world_cases.lesson: Social proof can be purchased

safeguards.action: Verify social proof sources independently
safeguards.implementation: Check for paid promotions, fake reviews

failure_modes.name: Pluralistic Ignorance
failure_modes.description: Everyone privately disagrees but publicly conforms
failure_modes.mechanism: Each person assumes others' silence means agreement

real_world_cases.name: Emperor's New Clothes in Corporations
real_world_cases.what_happened: Bad strategies continue because no one speaks up
real_world_cases.failure_point: Each person thinks they're the only one with doubts
real_world_cases.lesson: Silence is not agreement

safeguards.action: Create anonymous feedback channels
safeguards.implementation: Regular anonymous surveys, designated devil's advocate

failure_modes.name: Social Proof Velocity Trap
failure_modes.description: Rapid adoption signals quality when it signals only virality
failure_modes.mechanism: Fast growth triggers FOMO and assumption of value

real_world_cases.name: WeWork
real_world_cases.what_happened: Rapid growth and celebrity investors created illusion of value
real_world_cases.failure_point: Growth rate used as proxy for business quality
real_world_cases.lesson: Viral growth ≠ sustainable business

safeguards.action: Separate growth metrics from unit economics
safeguards.implementation: Always calculate: profitable at scale?

failure_modes.name: Selective Evidence Gathering
failure_modes.description: Only seeking information that confirms existing beliefs
failure_modes.mechanism: Brain rewards finding confirming evidence with dopamine

real_world_cases.name: Kodak Digital Camera Denial
real_world_cases.what_happened: Kodak invented digital camera but dismissed its potential
real_world_cases.failure_point: Leadership sought evidence film would persist
real_world_cases.outcome: Bankruptcy despite inventing the disrupting technology
real_world_cases.lesson: You can have the answer and still miss it through confirmation bias

safeguards.action: Actively seek disconfirming evidence
safeguards.implementation: Before deciding, list 3 reasons you might be wrong

failure_modes.name: Interpretation Bias
failure_modes.description: Interpreting ambiguous evidence as confirming
failure_modes.mechanism: Same data seen differently based on prior beliefs

real_world_cases.name: Value Investor Holding Losers
real_world_cases.what_happened: Investors interpret falling prices as 'better value'
real_world_cases.failure_point: Price drop could signal new information, not opportunity
real_world_cases.lesson: Cheap can always get cheaper for good reason

safeguards.action: Pre-commit to interpretation rules
safeguards.implementation: Define in advance what evidence would change your mind

failure_modes.name: Memory Bias
failure_modes.description: Better recall of confirming than disconfirming evidence
failure_modes.mechanism: Confirming memories are emotionally tagged for easier retrieval

safeguards.action: Keep written records of all predictions and outcomes
safeguards.implementation: Decision journal with pre-mortems

failure_modes.name: Source Credibility Bias
failure_modes.description: Trusting sources that confirm, dismissing those that don't
failure_modes.mechanism: We attribute credibility based on agreement, not accuracy

safeguards.action: Evaluate source credibility before knowing their conclusion
safeguards.implementation: Blind evaluation of methodology

failure_modes.name: Hypothesis Persistence
failure_modes.description: Maintaining beliefs even after evidence is discredited
failure_modes.mechanism: Initial belief creates mental framework that persists

safeguards.action: Practice belief updating with Bayesian thinking
safeguards.implementation: Assign probabilities, update with new evidence

failure_modes.name: Obligation Exploitation
failure_modes.description: Being manipulated through unsolicited gifts or favors
failure_modes.mechanism: Deep evolutionary programming to repay debts

real_world_cases.name: Pharmaceutical Industry Gifts to Doctors
real_world_cases.what_happened: Free lunches, conference trips, samples influenced prescribing
real_world_cases.failure_point: Doctors believed they were immune to influence
real_world_cases.lesson: No one is immune to reciprocity - not even experts

safeguards.action: Refuse gifts from those who want something
safeguards.implementation: Zero-gift policy from vendors/salespeople

failure_modes.name: Disproportionate Reciprocity
failure_modes.description: Returning large favors for small ones
failure_modes.mechanism: Desire to discharge obligation exceeds rational calculation

safeguards.action: Evaluate favors independently of who gave them
safeguards.implementation: Would I do this if a stranger asked?

failure_modes.name: Reciprocity in Negotiations
failure_modes.description: Making concessions because the other side did
failure_modes.mechanism: Concession triggers obligation to reciprocate

real_world_cases.name: Door-in-the-Face Technique
real_world_cases.what_happened: Salespeople make extreme request, then 'concede' to real ask
real_world_cases.failure_point: Buyer feels obligated to accept 'compromise'
real_world_cases.outcome: Agreeing to things you wouldn't otherwise
real_world_cases.lesson: Manufactured concessions aren't real concessions

safeguards.action: Evaluate offers on absolute merit, not relative to anchors
safeguards.implementation: Ignore their first offer entirely

failure_modes.name: Reciprocity Chains
failure_modes.description: Getting trapped in escalating exchange of favors
failure_modes.mechanism: Each exchange creates new obligation

safeguards.action: Set clear boundaries on favor exchanges
safeguards.implementation: Explicit agreements, not implicit obligations

failure_modes.name: Negative Reciprocity Spiral
failure_modes.description: Retaliating against perceived slights, escalating conflict
failure_modes.mechanism: Negative actions trigger stronger negative responses

safeguards.action: Pause before retaliating
safeguards.implementation: 24-hour rule before responding to perceived slights

failure_modes.name: Recency Bias
failure_modes.description: Overweighting recent events in probability estimates
failure_modes.mechanism: Recent memories are more vivid and accessible

real_world_cases.name: Post-Crash Risk Aversion
real_world_cases.what_happened: Investors stay out of markets for years after crashes
real_world_cases.failure_point: Recent crash dominates probability estimates
real_world_cases.lesson: The best time to invest is often when it feels worst

safeguards.action: Use base rates, not recent events
safeguards.implementation: Look at 50+ year data, not last 5 years

failure_modes.name: Vividness Bias
failure_modes.description: Overweighting dramatic events vs mundane ones
failure_modes.mechanism: Emotional events create stronger memories

real_world_cases.name: Fear of Flying vs Driving
real_world_cases.what_happened: People fear flying but not driving despite statistics
real_world_cases.failure_point: Plane crashes are vivid; car crashes are routine
real_world_cases.lesson: Dramatic ≠ probable

safeguards.action: Always check actual statistics
safeguards.implementation: Base rate before gut feel

failure_modes.name: Media Availability Distortion
failure_modes.description: Believing what's reported is what's common
failure_modes.mechanism: News reports unusual events, creating false frequency perception

safeguards.action: Recognize news selection bias
safeguards.implementation: If it's news, it's probably rare

failure_modes.name: Personal Experience Overgeneralization
failure_modes.description: Treating personal experience as representative
failure_modes.mechanism: Own experiences are most available

safeguards.action: Seek statistical data over anecdotes
safeguards.implementation: N=1 is not evidence

failure_modes.name: Availability Cascade
failure_modes.description: Repeated exposure makes things seem more true/likely
failure_modes.mechanism: Familiarity breeds perceived validity

safeguards.action: Distinguish familiarity from truth
safeguards.implementation: Ask: 'Do I believe this because it's true or because I've heard it often?'
